title: Obama Visits Florida to Win Over Older Voters
content:
“ The president is extraordinarily out of touch with how America ’ s economy works and with how individuals pursuing their dreams in this country have built America , ” he told a Tampa station . “ The president thinks that it ’ s government that should take responsibility for all the successful businesses in this country . ”
Mr. Obama ’ s trip to Florida is his seventh of the year . He stopped in Jacksonville and West Palm Beach on Thursday and travels to Fort Myers and Orlando on Friday .
The Obama campaign is so intent on winning Florida and its electoral votes that it began opening offices here more than a year ago and in recent weeks showed millions of dollars of advertisements in the state . But while Mr. Obama won Florida in 2008 , he remains effectively tied with Mr. Romney .
A poll conducted for The Miami Herald , The Tampa Bay Times and other news organizations last week found that 46 percent of likely Florida voters support Mr. Obama , and 45 percent support Mr. Romney . Particularly worrisome for the president : more Florida voters than not believe his policies have made the economy worse and want his health care law repealed .
Matthew T. Corrigan , a political scientist at the University of North Florida , said Mr. Obama has the advantages of incumbency and early organization while Mr. Romney has momentum from the economy . “ It ’ s conceivable for the president to lose Florida and have other ways to go , ” he said . “ But I think for Romney , it ’ s a must-win state . ”
Mr. Obama ’ s focus on older Americans reflects both their power in Florida and the president ’ s troubles attracting them . Voters 65 and over represented 22 percent of the Florida electorate in 2008 , compared with 16 percent nationally . But many are skeptical of Mr. Obama ’ s health care law and plans for Medicare after Republicans have attacked Democrats for shifting money from the program to pay for the new health law .

“ Democrats are focusing on that because Republicans have made inroads with seniors in Florida and it ’ s not the reliably Democratic voting bloc it used to be , ” Mr. Corrigan said .
Democrats insisted Mr. Obama will prevail . “ What ’ s unique about Florida , ” said Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida , the Democratic National Committee chairwoman , “ is we have demographic groups that I think are going to be particularly moved by the dramatic contrast between Mitt Romney ’ s record and his proposals , and President Obama ’ s record and the direction he wants to continue to move this country in . ”
At both stops Thursday , Mr. Obama pressed the argument that Mr. Romney ’ s plans would hurt older Americans . Older Floridians saved an average of $ 600 last year on prescription drug costs because the Obama health care law helped close the so-called doughnut hole in coverage , according to the Obama campaign . The law also helped seniors with free preventive care and annual wellness visits .
The president took aim at Mr. Romney ’ s support for a plan to overhaul Medicare by providing recipients vouchers to obtain health care insurance on the private market . Mr. Obama argued vouchers would never cover the full price , costing older Americans more than $ 6,000 a year . The Romney campaign called that a distortion and pointed to PolitiFact , an independent fact-checking operation that has deemed Mr. Obama ’ s claim “ mostly false. ” Mr. Romney ’ s aides also noted Mr. Obama used $ 500 billion in Medicare savings to pay for his health care law .
For his part , Mr. Romney spent the day in Massachusetts , where he visited Middlesex Truck and Coach in Boston to attack Mr. Obama again for saying that successful business owners did not get there without government help .
“ Now I know that some people think what the president said was just a gaffe , ” Mr. Romney said . “ It wasn ’ t a gaffe . It was instead his ideology . ”
Brian Maloney , 69 , who has been in business since 1980 , was an ideal embodiment of Mr. Romney ’ s message . “ I take umbrage at the suggestion that people don ’ t start and build businesses , ” he said . “ I started out with 50 bucks and worked with my hands to afford grad school at night. ” Government , he added , brought only complicated regulations : “ It ’ s overbearing . ”
Two local politicians showed up to undercut Mr. Romney ’ s message . “ I ’ m very happy that former Governor Romney found his way here , ” said Tito Jackson , a city councilman from the area , which is largely black and Hispanic . “ But you know what ? He didn ’ t create jobs when he was governor . He didn ’ t find himself in this community that often . ”
Mr. Romney , whose campaign mastered such tactics during the Republican primaries , brushed off the protest .
“ Oh , that ’ s the nature of politics , ” he told the business owner . “ There are always two teams . We ’ re always bothering each other ’ s teams . ”
